Hello! Welcome to Womenâ€™s Cycling Weekly issue 33 ğŸš´â€â™€ï¸

Itâ€™s been 10 days since the last WCW and a LOT of racing has happened. After the dry spell that was June all of the stage races have come at once, like buses we were waiting for, while starving, and in the rain. One of those races was, of course, the Giro Donne.Â 

Ah yes, the Giro Donne. Those who were holding their breath for a well-organised race with consistent live tv coverage, will be remembered as optimistic to a fault. Credit for the forthcoming paraphrased analogy goes to my colleague Abby Mickey (legend) but the Giro Donne really is like that toxic boyfriend you keep going back to â€“ itâ€™s not going to change! If that sounds harsh then consider me the random girl you just met in the club toilets who is comforting you about said ex.Â 

But seriously, itâ€™s actually just the product of a weariness borne out of the womenâ€™s peloton consistently getting far less than they deserve from this race, and fans consistently being let down by a lack of coverage or promotion. Because 6km one day, 34km the next, and nothing on the queen stage is not good enough, the end. Donâ€™t @ me.

NewsÂ ğŸ“°

  • Ruth WinderÂ will retire from pro cycling at the end of 2021, the 28-year-old American said in a video released by the team: â€œIâ€™ve reached so many of my dreams already but my heart misses home while Iâ€™m on the road so much of the year.â€ Best of luck to Ruth.
  • Spectators will be barred from events at theÂ Olympic GamesÂ in Tokyo amidst rising concern for Covid-19 in the area with the city entering a state of emergency.
  • The Cyclistsâ€™ AllianceÂ andÂ CyclingTipsÂ have released a jersey in collaboration with Black Sheep, the concept is â€˜EQUALSâ€™ and the jersey is stunning imo. You can read more about the story behind it and have a look at the collectionÂ here.

Giro Donne

  • Four riders won their first ever Giro Donne stages this year:Â Lorena Wiebes,Â Emma Norsgaard,Â Ashleigh Moolman Pasio, andÂ Coryn Rivera.Â 
  • At the other end of the spectrum, the GOAT,Â Marianne Vos, now has 30 Giro Donne stage wins, and check out this stat:Â 

Crunched some numbers this morning to try and work out the king, ended up crowning a queen.

Cav has won 34 of the 192 (17.7%) Tour stages he's completed, Merckx 34 of 179 (19%).

Vos? Well, she's won 30 of the 91 Giro Donne stages she's completed â€“ 32.9%! ğŸ#TDF2021 #GiroDonne

â€” Will Newton (@InsidePeloton96) July 11, 2021
  • BothÂ Bizkaia DurangoÂ andÂ Tibco-SVBÂ were forced to pull out of the Giro Donne due to covid positives within their teams. Hopefully all those who were affected are healthy and we see them return to racing soon.Â 
  • Tayler WilesÂ ofÂ Trek-SegafredoÂ also abandoned the race due to a non-Covid-related illness.
  • Krista Doebel-HicockÂ ofÂ Rally CyclingÂ left the race with a broken arm.Â 
  • Cecilie Uttrup LudwigÂ crashed during the TTT prologue and pulled out of the race before stage 8.Â 
  • Amanda SprattÂ also pulled out due to injuries from a crash on stage 8.Â 
  • Marianne VosÂ pulled out of the race ahead of stage 10 in order to focus on the Olympic Games. Eddy Merckx is penning his reaction as we speak.Â 
  • And finally,Â Heidi FranzÂ (off of brilliant audio diaries for Freewheeling) spoke out about her awful experience ofÂ being bullied while in a grupetoÂ on stage 9 â€” not cool and hopefully Heidi is okay!
